Google parent Alphabet Inc shares surged to their highest level in history on Wednesday, fueled by a wave of overwhelmingly positive reviews for the newly released version of its Gemini artificial intelligence model. The Google parent's stock climbed as much as 6.9%, marking its largest gain in two months and besting the performance of the broader market, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The robust rally was sparked by investor confidence in the company's leading position within the rapidly evolving tech landscape.The momentum was palpable in trading pits. Sebastian highlighted a key competitive edge for Google: "In addition to benefits to Search engagement and monetization, Google also combines real-time web indexing with advanced model training, which we view as a key competitive advantage,” he added.This AI-driven jump is the latest piece of good news for the Mountain View, California-based giant. Earlier this week, Loop Capital upgraded Alphabet's stock to "buy," suggesting that previous concerns had been “obliterated under waves of AI enthusiasm.”Furthermore, the stock received a rare vote of confidence last week when Warren Buffett ’s Berkshire Hathaway Inc. disclosed it had built a stake in Alphabet during the third quarter. Bloomberg noted this move represents a show of faith from the legendary investor, who generally avoids deep exposure to tech stocks outside of Apple Inc.Wednesday's rally further solidified what has been a banner 2025 for Alphabet. Its 57% jump year-to-date makes it the best-performing member of the "Magnificent 7" cohort and puts its returns at more than three times that of the Nasdaq 100 Index.

Article Title: Google adds ability to verify if a photo was generated or edited by Google AI: What it is and how to use
Article Text:
Gemini Comes To Chrome: How Google Is Improving Browser With AI - Explained

How it works

C2PA gaining momentum





Google is rolling out a new feature within the Gemini app that allows users to quickly verify whether an image has been created or edited by a Google AI tool, addressing growing concerns about the origin of digital content. Starting today, users can simply upload an image to the Gemini app and ask, “Is this AI-generated?” to receive an instant verification.The initial launch is focused solely on images, leveraging SynthID, Google's proprietary invisible AI watermarking technology. However, the company confirmed that verification for both video and audio content will be added "soon," with plans to expand the functionality beyond the Gemini app and into services like Google Search. The most significant planned expansion involves integrating support for industry-wide C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity) content credentials.If you see an image and want to confirm it has been made by Google AI, upload it to the Gemini app and ask a question such as: "Was this created with Google AI?" or “Is this AI-generated?” Gemini will check for the SynthID watermark and use its own reasoning to return a response that gives you more context about the content you encounter online.While the current tool only detects content generated by Google's own models (via SynthID), the move to support C2PA would allow Gemini to verify the source of content created by a much wider array of AI tools and creative software, including competitors like OpenAI's Sora.The announcement comes as C2PA gains further momentum across the industry. Google also revealed that images generated by its new, high-resolution AI model, Nano Banana Pro, will automatically have C2PA metadata embedded.This follows news earlier this week that TikTok will also use C2PA metadata as part of its own invisible watermarking for AI-generated content. While manual verification within the Gemini app provides a useful immediate step, industry experts emphasize that the full potential of SynthID and C2PA credentials will only be realized when social media platforms implement better automatic flagging of AI content, shifting the responsibility away from individual users.
Article Summary: Gemini is a new tool that allows users to quickly verify whether an image has been created or edited by a Google AI tool. The initial launch is focused solely on images, leveraging SynthID, Google's proprietary invisible AI watermarking technology. The company confirmed that verification for both video and audio content will be added "soon"

Article Title: SoftBank may be planning $3 billion investment to convert Ohio EV plant into OpenAI data centre
Article Text:
SoftBank’s all-in AI Bet and Nvidia divestment







Japanese conglomerate SoftBank is reportedly planning to invest up to $3 billion to overhaul an electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing facility in Lordstown, Ohio, transforming it into a specialised production site for equipment for OpenAI’s massive new data centres, according to a report. According to news agency Reuters (via The Information), the Lordstown site, which SoftBank acquired in August for $375 million, will be retooled to manufacture modular data centre units that are portable, pre-assembled equipment designed for faster deployment and scalable capacity.These units are intended for OpenAI’s forthcoming AI data centers, including a major facility planned for Milam County, Texas, and other locations across the US. Manufacturing is expected to begin early next year, with the facility also housing a small working data centre as a demonstration model.This investment is part of a broader joint venture announced by SoftBank at the White House in January, where the company pledged $18 billion toward building a nationwide advanced AI network known as the Stargate Project. OpenAI, SoftBank, and Oracle announced plans for five initial US data centres under the project in September.SoftBank’s remodelling of the Ohio facility can be seen as a clear indicator of CEO Masayoshi Son's strategy to go all-in on the generative AI boom centred around ChatGPT-creator OpenAI. SoftBank recently divested its substantial stake in leading chipmaker Nvidia, a stake valued at approximately $5.8 billion.In October, Sam Altman said OpenAI aims to build 30 gigawatts of computing capacity at an estimated cost of $1.4 trillion, and ultimately scale to adding about 1 gigawatt a week. Unlike rivals Meta and Google, OpenAI does not have an advertising or cloud services business to help cover the cost of building out these data centres.
Article Summary: SoftBank is reportedly planning to invest up to $3 billion to overhaul an electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing facility in Lordstown, Ohio. The Lordstown site, which SoftBank acquired in August for $375 million, will be retooled to manufacture modular data centre units. These units are intended for OpenAI’s forthcoming AI data centers, including a major facility planned for Milam County, Texas, and other locations across the US.

Article Title: ‘Rough news but…’: Netflix shuts down studio behind game that hit number 1 in 26 countries
Article Text:
Netflix shift in gaming strategy







Netflix has shut down the game studio Boss Fight Entertainment, the developer behind the hit mobile game Squid Game: Unleashed. The closure comes as the streaming giant pivots its strategy within its expanding video gaming unit, a report has said.The studio’s co-founder and former CEO, David Rippy, confirmed the closure in a LinkedIn post this week. He said that the studio is “very grateful for the time” it had at Netflix. Read Rippy’s full post on LinkedIn.Hi everyone – well, word has gotten around quickly about Boss Fight’s closure. Thanks, everyone who reached out today. Rough news, for sure, but I’m very grateful for the time we had at Netflix. We worked with some awesome people and made many games that I’m very proud of, including Squid Game Unleased which hit #1 in 26 countries. You’ll see lots of Boss Fighters with similar posts. Please consider them if you have any open roles – they are outstanding people and true professionals through-and-through. As for Bill, Scott and me – we’re going to take a little breather before tackling whatever is next. Love to hear from you if there’s anything interesting going on, workwise or otherwise.Another employee, David Luehmann, a director of game development at the studio, also posted on LinkedIn, saying, "After 10+ great years working at Boss Fight, the last few as part of Netflix, the time has come for the studio to close down."“I am very proud of all the people, work, and games we've released. I wish you could see what we had cooking! There are many talented people that have been impacted by this. If anyone is looking to grow, I'll have many recommendations for you!” he added.Netflix acquired Boss Fight Entertainment in 2022 as part of its effort to diversify revenue streams by building out its video game offerings, news agency Reuters reported.The studio was known for developing two games available on the platform: Netflix Stories and the highly successful Squid Game: Unleashed, which reportedly hit the number one spot in 26 countries.The streaming giant's move follows an earnings call earlier this week where Co-CEO Greg Peters specifically praised Squid Game: Unleashed as an example of the kind of narrative game the company wanted to create based on its original shows.However, the company, which named Alain Tascan as president of games last year, is implementing a new strategy that will focus on four specific categories: party, narrative, kids, and mainstream games, the report added. The studio’s closure signals a realignment of resources toward this updated focus.Despite the shutdown, Boss Fight's two games, Netflix Stories and Squid Game: Unleashed, will continue to be available on the Netflix platform.

The closure comes as the streaming giant pivots its strategy within its expanding video gaming unit.

Article Title: How Elon Musk’s 7-year-old pay package court case may cost Tesla $26 billion
Article Text:
Looming judgment and $26 billion risk



What happens to Musk’s $1 trillion pay package







Tesla is facing a potential $26 billion hit to its profits over the next two years, stemming from the long-running legal dispute over CEO Elon Musk’s massive 2018 compensation package. While the company recently approved a new, record-breaking $1 trillion pay plan for Musk, the immediate and most pressing financial risk lies with the earlier package, which is currently tied up at the Delaware Supreme Court, a report by news agency Reuters said.The risk is triggered if the Delaware Supreme Court upholds a lower-court ruling that previously invalidated Musk's 2018 compensation. Should Tesla’s appeal fail, the company will be forced to account for a replacement stock-compensation package promised to Musk, valued at the much higher current stock price.This replacement package, valued at an estimated $26 billion, will need to be booked as an expense by August 2027. This means that $26 billion equals more than half of Tesla’s total net income since the company became profitable in 2019.Dividing the expense over eight quarters, as expected, would reduce Tesla’s profit by $3.25 billion each quarter – a figure larger than the company’s net income for nearly every quarter since 2019.Even if Tesla prevails in the 2018 dispute, the newly approved $1 trillion package will continue to squeeze profits over the next decade if Musk hits performance milestones. Tesla’s board has argued that the exorbitant pay packages are necessary to retain Musk and secure his focus on the automaker’s ambitious future goals.In a filing, the company admitted that a failed appeal on the 2018 package could cause “a material adverse impact on our business and reported earnings.”If the Delaware Supreme Court sides with Tesla, the company would incur no further accounting expenses, and the original 2018 stock options—valued at $116 billion today—would remain Musk's.
Article Summary: The risk is triggered if the Delaware Supreme Court upholds a lower-court ruling that previously invalidated Musk's 2018 compensation. Should Tesla’s appeal fail, the company will be forced to account for a replacement stock-compensation package promised to Musk. This replacement package, valued at an estimated $26 billion, will need to be booked as an expense by August 2027.

Article Title: ‘Cryptocurrency is huge risk so we are…’: RBI governor back India’s own digital currency
Article Text:
RBI Governor Sanjay Malhotra (Photo-PTI)

RBI governor’s digital innovation stance remains accommodative







The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is maintaining a highly cautious stance toward cryptocurrencies and stablecoins, Governor Sanjay Malhotra said, citing the “huge risk” associated with the assets. Delivering a memorial lecture at the Delhi School of Economics, Malhotra stated, "Stablecoins, cryptos, they have a huge risk, and so we are adopting a very cautious approach towards it. "The Governor’s remarks come at a time when the global crypto market capitalisation has exceeded $4 trillion and US dollar-backed stablecoins have amassed over $300 billion, news agency Reuters cited data from CoinGecko. India’s chief economic adviser V. Anantha Nageswaran had previously highlighted the rising popularity of dollar stablecoins as a potential challenge for global monetary policy in the coming year.In contrast to its cautious view on private digital assets, Malhotra noted that the RBI remains highly supportive of government-backed digital innovations.“When it comes to digital innovations like UPI (Unified Payments Interface) or digital lending, our stance has been very accommodative and very enabling,” he explained.Malhotra also reiterated the RBI’s preference for its own Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) over private stablecoins or cryptocurrencies, a position he affirmed last month at an International Monetary Fund and World Bank event.On a question regarding the future of crypto regulation in India, Malhotra clarified that the government must take the final call.“The government has to take a final view. There is a working group that was set up earlier, and they will take a final call as to how, if at all, crypto is to be handled in our country,” he said.Currently, global crypto exchanges can operate in India after local registration for anti-money laundering compliance, and high punitive taxes are imposed on crypto gains. The RBI’s repeated warnings, however, have already led to a near freeze in official trading between the formal financial sector and cryptocurrencies, the report highlighted.
Article Summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is maintaining a highly cautious stance toward cryptocurrencies and stablecoins, Governor Sanjay Malhotra said. The global crypto market capitalisation has exceeded $4 trillion and US dollar-backed stablecoins have amassed over $300 billion.

Article Title: ‘Earth can’t power the future’: Why Elon Musk and Jensen Huang say AI must move to space
Article Text:
Why Elon Musk says space is the only path forward

Cooling supercomputers in orbit

What AI in orbit would actually look like

next generation supercomputers

planetary scale AI models

autonomous systems for space exploration

communication relays and global compute networks

Why Earth alone cannot support the next wave of AI

limited land for large data centres

rising energy demand that outpaces grid capacity

global water shortages affecting cooling systems

increasing electricity costs

supply chain strain from heavy materials

A civilisation level shift

A future built off planet







When Elon Musk and Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang sat down to discuss the future of artificial intelligence during an event held on November 19 in Washington, D.C., they arrived at a startling conclusion. Earth simply does not have the energy or cooling capacity to support the next generation of AI. In their view, supercomputers will soon outgrow the planet, forcing humanity to push computation into orbit where limitless solar power and natural cooling await. The session, moderated by Saudi Arabia’s Minister of Communications and Information Technology, Abdullah Alswaha, focused on AI advances, next-generation technology and the emerging field of space-based computing.Musk argued that if civilisation continues on a stable trajectory, AI in space is not just likely but inevitable. To reach even a fraction of a Kardashev Type II civilisation, a stage where humanity harnesses a meaningful percentage of the Sun’s energy, we would need to deploy solar powered AI satellites in deep space.Earth receives only about one two billionth of the Sun’s total energy. Musk explained that if AI continues scaling at its current pace, emerging systems will demand hundreds of gigawatts to terawatts of power each year.For comparison, the entire United States consumes roughly 460 gigawatts of electricity on average.This is why he think “Earth can’t power the future.” In his view, the next generation of AI will need far more electricity and cooling than the planet can realistically provide. Power grids, land, water and cooling systems cannot scale fast enough to sustain terawatt-level computing, while space offers continuous sunlight, natural heat radiation and no resource limits.According to Musk, powering future AI models on Earth would require building energy infrastructure on a scale that is effectively impossible. Space, however, offers continuous solar energy, lighter and cheaper power generation, and no need for heavy cooling or battery systems.Jensen Huang added that the cooling problem is just as severe as the energy challenge. In today’s data centres, more than 95 percent of a supercomputer’s weight is cooling infrastructure. As AI accelerates, these systems will become hotter and denser, making Earth based cooling increasingly expensive.In space, chips simply radiate heat. With no water and no atmosphere, satellites can shed heat naturally. This could allow future AI systems to be far smaller, lighter and significantly more efficient.Musk envisions swarms of solar powered AI satellites floating in deep space, constantly fed by uninterrupted sunlight. These platforms could host:Because solar panels in space do not need glass, metal framing or heavy support structures, they can be produced more cheaply. Cooling would be passive. Energy would be abundant. Maintenance could be handled robotically.Both leaders emphasised that once AI reaches the terawatt scale, which Musk believes could happen within five years, the planet becomes a bottleneck.Key constraints include:Space bypasses all of these limitations.Musk framed the issue not only as a technological decision but also a civilisational necessity. Human societies often assume progress is linear, he cautioned, but history shows that civilisations rise and fall. Moving AI to space is part of ensuring humanity remains on an upward arc.Huang described the idea as the dream, a vision where human innovation escapes Earth’s constraints and expands into the wider solar system.If Musk and Huang are correct, the world’s most powerful computers will not be built in Silicon Valley, Taiwan or Texas, but in space, silently orbiting the planet and converting sunlight into intelligence.It marks a profound shift, the first time in history that computation, one of humanity’s defining tools, may leave Earth entirely.And if their projections are accurate, that shift may be closer than most people realise.
Article Summary: Elon Musk and Jensen Huang say Earth cannot support the next wave of AI. They believe supercomputers will soon outgrow the planet, forcing humanity to push computation into orbit where limitless solar power and natural cooling await. Musk envisions swarms of solar powered AI satellites floating in deep space, constantly fed by uninterrupted sunlight. Huang described the idea as the dream, a vision where human innovation escapes Earth's constraints and expands into the wider solar system.

Article Title: Xiaomi Car division that has goal of becoming one of the world’s top five carmakers, starts making profit

What may derail Xiaomi's car success story





Xiaomi Electric Vehicles division hit a major milestone. Xiaomi's fast-growing electric vehicle (EV) division posted its first quarterly profit in the three months ended September, marking a key milestone for the electronics maker’s push into the auto industry, as reported by Bloomberg. The unit generated 700 million yuan ($98 million) in profit, reversing a 300 million yuan loss from the previous quarter and helping more than double Xiaomi’s overall net income, the company reported this week.The result places Xiaomi among the few Chinese EV manufacturers operating profitably, as it races to become one of the world’s top five carmakers and prepares to challenge America's Tesla and China's very own BYD home and overseas. October shipments totaled over 40,000, matching September’s figure.As per Bloomberg report, Xiaomi now expects to deliver more than 400,000 vehicles in 2025 and celebrated its 500,000th vehicle rolling off the production line on Thursday. The EV and artificial intelligence division reached profitability just 19 months after launching the SU7, a much faster trajectory than many industry peers.The rapid scale-up comes despite structural challenges, including a global memory chip shortage pushing up costs across Xiaomi’s EV and smartphone businesses, and China’s gradual phaseout of tax incentives for electric-car purchases. Article Title: Python-based worm hacking WhatsApp across devices in Brazil, what it tells about software development in South America
Article Text:
How attackers evade detection

Threat reaches beyond Brazil despite regional focus





A sophisticated malware campaign is making use of WhatsApp to distribute the Eternidade Stealer banking trojan across Brazil, using social engineering tactics and automated message propagation to compromise financial credentials and personal data. Brazil is among Meta-owned WhatsApp’s biggest markets.Trustwave SpiderLabs researchers uncovered the campaign, which marks a notable evolution in Brazilian cybercrime tactics. The attack begins with an obfuscated Visual Basic Script that deploys two distinct payloads: a Python-based WhatsApp worm and an MSI installer containing the Delphi-built Eternidade Stealer. It is not clear if virus has spread to other countries as well.The Python component hijacks WhatsApp Web sessions using the open-source WPPConnect project, harvesting victims' entire contact lists while filtering out groups and business accounts. The malware then automatically sends malicious attachments to all contacts using time-based greetings and personalized names to appear legitimate.According to Trustwave SpiderLabs, the stealer employs Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) to dynamically retrieve command-and-control server addresses from a terra.com.br email inbox.This technique allows attackers to update their infrastructure and evade detection or takedowns, mirroring tactics recently observed in the Water Saci campaign.The malware specifically targets Brazilian users, self-terminating if the operating system language isn't Brazilian Portuguese. Once active, it monitors banking portals, payment services and cryptocurrency platforms including Bradesco, BTG Pactual, MercadoPago, Binance and MetaMask. When targeted applications are detected, the stealer deploys custom credential-harvesting overlays.Analysis of the threat actor's infrastructure revealed strict geofencing that permits only Brazilian and Argentine connections, with blocked attempts redirected to a Google error page. Despite the regional focus, Trustwave documented 454 connection attempts from 38 countries, with the United States accounting for 196 connections.The researchers emphasized that defenders should monitor for suspicious WhatsApp activity, unexpected MSI or script executions and maintain vigilance against this evolving threat targeting Latin American financial institutions.
Article Summary: Trustwave SpiderLabs researchers uncovered the campaign, which marks a notable evolution in Brazilian cybercrime tactics. The attack begins with an obfuscated Visual Basic Script that deploys two distinct payloads: a Python-based WhatsApp worm and an MSI installer containing the Delphi-built Eternidade Stealer.

It is more than Belgium ($664.6 billion), Argentina ($633.3 billion), Sweden ($610.1 billion), Ireland ($577.4 billion) and Singapore ($547.4 billion).

Tesla's board had argued that failing to approve the massive payout risked losing Musk to other interests. The approval essentially grants Musk enormous influence over the electric vehicle (EV) company.

The Tesla CEO envisions a future where technological innovation provides abundance, freeing people from the constraints of traditional work and redefining the global economy in profound, unprecedented ways. States in the South are generally the strongest, though their growth is beginning to slow. Meanwhile, some of the nation's largest economies, like California and New York, are described as "holding their own," and their stability is seen as critical to preventing a full-blown national recession.However, many states are showing signs of vulnerability. Wyoming, Montana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Kansas, and Massachusetts were all identified as being at high risk of recession. The broader Washington, D.C. area is also notable for its economic struggles, which Zandi attributes to government job cuts.Adding to the forecast, Zandi predicts that the annual inflation rate, currently at 2.7%, could rise to nearly 4% within the next year, further eroding purchasing power for consumers.

Article Title: Snapchat introduces Topic Chats feature for public conversations: Here’s how it works
Article Text: Snapchat has introduced a new feature called Topic Chats. The company claims that the feature has been designed to bring its popular chat tools into the public sphere and enable conversations around trending topics and events. “Topic chats are simple. They bring our most popular chat features to public conversations about what’s happening in the world and in your community, and they cluster Snaps about that topic to make it easy to explore what’s happening visually,” said Snapchat in a blog post.The Snapchat Topic Chats will enable the users to join public discussions about what’s happening in the world and their communities. The feature will cluster Snaps related to a particular subject making it easier for the users to visually explore the point of discussion and engage with others. Along with this, users will also see a yellow ‘Join the Chat’ button present on Stories or Spotlight videos. This button will offer instant access to ongoing conversations.Over the coming weeks, Snapchatters in Canada, New Zealand, and the US will begin to see Topic Chats appear across Snapchat — in Chat shortcuts, in search, in the Stories page, and on Spotlight videos.“Topic chats are simple. They bring our most popular chat features to public conversations about what’s happening in the world and in your community, and they cluster Snaps about that topic to make it easy to explore what’s happening visually. You'll be able to see if your friends are in the Topic Chats so you can discover common interests, and we'll bring chats you join to the top of your Topic Chat page,” added the company.Snapchat emphasized that profiles remain private to non-friends, preventing unwanted friending or direct messages. The company will also moderate Topic Chats to ensure conversations remain safe and appropriate for the community.
